description: Dive into "Liverpool's Lens: Capturing Iconic Moments" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Liverpool's Lens: Capturing Iconic Moments

places.generalDescription: Liverpool Cathedral, also known as the Anglican Liverpool Cathedral, is a grand 20th-century place of worship that boasts the world's highest Gothic arches and a towering viewing tower. Despite its ancient appearance, it was actually completed in 1978 after 74 years of construction. Designed by Sir Giles Gilbert Scott, this masterpiece of Gothic Revival is Britain's largest cathedral and features contemporary visual art installations that add to its unique atmosphere.

sources.snippet: If you are into ancient history and architecture, you can check out the Anglican Cathedral in Liverpool, which is not only the largest but also the most popular place of worship in Liverpool. The cathedral was built between the year 1904 to 1978, and it‚Äôs Gothic revival architecture, with all its soaring arches and the viewing towers offering stunning views of the city. The place gives you a vintage feel, making it one of the Top Photo Shoot Locations in Liverpool.
sources.shortName: 20 Top Photography Spots In Liverpool: From Cafes To Museums

sources.snippet: One of two cathedrals in the city, Liverpool Cathedral was built in 1904 but has been altered and re-imagined many times since. The cathedral was originally designed by Giles Gilbert Scott who also designed Battersea Power Station in London, and England‚Äôs iconic red telephone box. Liverpool Cathedral is the longest in the world, with an external length of 189 metres.
sources.shortName: 25 Best Things to Do in Liverpool (England)

sources.snippet: Liverpool Cathedral is Britain's largest Cathedral and the 5th largest in Europe so you know it‚Äôs going to be something pretty special inside and out. Head inside to take in the cavernous space and stunning architecture with beautiful features everywhere you look. See if you can spot the piece of light art of artist Tracy Emin for a great photo opportunity too.
sources.shortName: VisitLiverpool | Liverpool's Best Instagram Locations

sources.snippet: If you are into your architecture then there are plenty of things to explore in and around the cathedral. There are numerous stain glass windows which can make for some really bright and colourful photos. It is quite dark at some points inside, so you may need a tripod if you're going to be using a slower shutter speed.
sources.shortName: The Best Places For Photography In Liverpool

places.name: Liverpool Cathedral

reviews.text: Absolutely beautiful building.  Accessible with 1 transit wheelchair available to use. Plenty of parking including blue badge although charges apply. Lovely cafe serving great lunches, cakes etc. Lift available,  clean toilets and Accessible toilets available.  Nice gift shop inside cathedral. Choir and organ sounded amazing and we could join in the service if we wanted to. Gorgeous architecture,  stained glass windows etc. Very helpful staff. The people of Liverpool are very welcoming. ‚ù§Ô∏è

Wow such an impressive building inside as well as out! Large car park at good rates, the cafe is a bistro so bit posh for me but cuppa, baguette then scone and cream was okay. Other tables had the roast which looked yummy. So much to see and notice, easy to spend a few hours walking round. The volunteers\staff are really friendly and knowledgeable, relying on donations. I bought a ticket for the tower in the shop. ¬£7 was great value and it didn't seem like 108 steps as two lifts take you a long way up, and walking up looking down at the still bells makes you think! (I'm from Leeds so I haven't heard them) Staff member up the tower today was great, pointing buildings, areas, answering questions. Such a beautiful day, you can see for miles! Going back the opposite way down, lifts again to the cathedral. Really is worth the climb if you are able...

Liverpool Cathedral is an excellent display of architectural brilliance. It's soaring steeple ,which contributes to the Liverpool skyline, offers tours and brilliant views of the city. The church is free to enter, but to go to the top of the steeple is not. The shear scale of the cathedral is truly breathtaking featuring intricate and skilled designs. The interior of the building is equally as beautiful, with its large stain glass windows and carved stone arches. Of these arches, there is the ingenious whispering arch where the curvature of the archway allows for whispers to travel to the other side of the room. Finally, the church features a large gift shop and free toilets alongside its brilliant religious facilities. Overall, the church is definitely worth a visit if you are in the area.

places.address: St James‚Äô Mount, Liverpool, L1 7AZ, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: Royal Albert Dock Liverpool is a vibrant waterfront area that has undergone a stunning renovation, shedding its industrial past to become one of Liverpool's most popular tourist attractions. It features a mix of museums, art galleries, family-friendly restaurants, and shops. The dock boasts the largest collection of Grade-listed buildings in the UK and offers picturesque waterfront views. Visitors can explore gift shops, cafes, and restaurants while enjoying pop-up food courts and love locks overlooking the Mersey.

sources.snippet: The Royal Albert Dock is the largest collection of Grade II listed buildings in the UK and is one of the top spots to visit in the city for photo opportunities. Walk around the Dock to take in the sights and sounds of the waterfront venue where you‚Äôll find Liverpool Mountain, The Beatles Story, Tate Liverpool and the Maritime Museum. You‚Äôre spoilt for choice on backdrops for your photos here.
sources.shortName: VisitLiverpool | Liverpool's Best Instagram Locations

sources.snippet: Historically Liverpool was a port city, and the Royal Albert Dock is unquestionably the ordinary example. Every place on the dock is lovely for photographs, especially come here after the afternoon and have a walk nearby to grasp what you can shoot. You can take a picture opposite of the entry to the Beatles Story, then take a selfie in front of the waterfront horizon.
sources.shortName: 12 Instagrammable places in Liverpool

sources.snippet: The Albert Dock is without a doubt one of the most iconic areas of our city. From The Tate art gallery, to its many bars and restaurants, to the Beatles museum ‚Äì you‚Äôre spoilt for choice when it comes to sights to get a shot of. Personally, we think it‚Äôs prettiest at dusk when you‚Äôre likely to catch a scenic sunset.
sources.shortName: No Filter Required - 15 Of Liverpool‚Äôs Most Instagrammable Spots

sources.snippet: The Royal Albert Dock is brimming with history dating back to 1839. The dock was completely regenerated in 1988 to what it is today. With a vast range of restaurant, bars, hotels, museums and galleries it has plenty of options for the perfect selfie spot.
sources.shortName: The Most Instagrammable Spots In Liverpool

sources.snippet: Another great photo spot in Liverpool is Albert Docks ‚Äì a historic converted dock that is now home to Tate Modern Liverpool and various lovely shops and restaurants.
sources.shortName: 10+ Amazing Instagrammable Places in Liverpool (+ their exact locations)

places.name: Royal Albert Dock Liverpool

reviews.text: Fantastic! Quite pricey as you'd expect from a hot tourist spot but it looked great, food was great, shops were stunning. Had a fun family day out just walking about. Very romantic for a date I'd say. My favourite part were jelly fish in the docks tho. The water was dirty and they looked dead but love jellyfish.

Love this place, geat use of Liverpool fantastic historical docks.  Old rustic cobbles and brick with modern eateries and shops, some great museums here although check dates as closed for refurbishment.

Heritage, colour, and waterfront calm all in one stop.

This place blends historic red‚Äëbrick warehouses with bold public art, museums, and sweeping waterfront views. Flat and walkable (watch the cobbles), it's perfect for a slow wander, photo stops, and dipping into free museums like the Maritime and Museum of Liverpool.

Golden hour here is pure magic! the light on the water and brick is worth timing your visit for.

places.generalDescription: The Beatles Statue, unveiled in 2015, is a popular bronze sculpture of the legendary rock group located in central Liverpool. This iconic statue created by sculptor Andy Edwards is a must-visit for fans and tourists alike. It's a common spot for snapping selfies and experiencing a unique piece of memorabilia related to The Beatles' rich musical heritage in their hometown.

sources.snippet: The Beatles took over the world with their music and have made their name to the extent that there is a statue dedicated to them in Liverpool to give them a legendary tribute. So who wouldn‚Äôt want to click some really cool pictures in front of the legends of the music world?. The Beatles Pier Head statue is a bronze sculpture, weighing some 1.2 tonnes, featuring the group‚Äôs first public appearance in Liverpool.
sources.shortName: 20 Top Photography Spots In Liverpool: From Cafes To Museums

sources.snippet: The larger than life statues of the Fab Four are waiting for you to take your picture with them on Liverpool‚Äôs famous Waterfront. Find the four lads from Liverpool on Pier Head by the Liver Building where you‚Äôll always see a crowd of people wanting to get the ultimate Beatles shot - and we can see why!
sources.shortName: VisitLiverpool | Liverpool's Best Instagram Locations

sources.snippet: The Beatles are synonymous with Liverpool, and the city pays homage to the Fab Four in many ways. One of the most popular spots for Beatles fans is the Beatles Statue, located on the waterfront. This bronze statue depicts the band walking along the dock, and is a must-see for any Beatles fan.
sources.shortName: Top Liverpool Photo Spots: Scenic & Iconic Locations

sources.snippet: Lets face facts, are you even in Liverpool if you haven‚Äôt snapped a shot next to the Fab Four?!. The four lads stand tall just behind the Mersey Ferry Terminal, striding into the sunset, so take that huge stride and snap away while linking one of the city‚Äôs most famous attributes!
sources.shortName: Instagrammable spots in Liverpool you need to check out

sources.snippet: The Beatles Statue at Liverpool Pier head is definitely Instagram worthy. Get a photo with these larger than life size figures and look like you‚Äôre part of the fab four. The Beatles Statue is only a 10 minute walk from our  Cumberland and Sir Thomas Street locations.
sources.shortName: The Most Instagrammable Spots In Liverpool

sources.snippet: It is a statue of all four members of The Beatles group walking on the street. It is located on Pier Head str. L3 1BY and near Mersey Ferry Terminal.
sources.shortName: 12 Instagrammable places in Liverpool

places.name: The Beatles Statue

reviews.text:
A must-visit spot in Liverpool!
The Beatles statue is iconic on its own, but the best photos come when you capture it with the grand historic buildings in the background. It adds depth and really brings out the timeless atmosphere of the city. Try visiting around sunset or after rain - the reflections and light make the scene even more magical. Great place to feel the spirit of Liverpool and its legendary music history.

We love the Beatles and their songs, so happy that we able to stop by in Liverpool and take pictures with their statue here. We visited this place on May during weekdays, so not much crowd that time. The surrounding area also very beautiful to walk around üòç

The statues are amazing on the water front vendors singing Beatles tunes and lots of people all hanging out kids on the docs with skateboards looking at ships in the river some of them restaurants that u can board and have brunch on the river meeting people from other countries just very nice relaxing looking at the architecture and ships in the harbor plenty of shops and restaurants

places.address: Pier Head, Liverpool, L3 1BY, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: The Walker Art Gallery is a Victorian museum that showcases significant art pieces from the 12th century onwards, featuring works by renowned artists such as Degas and Hockney. It is one of the must-visit attractions in Liverpool, offering a cultural experience for art enthusiasts. After exploring the gallery, visitors can immerse themselves in local culture, dine at excellent restaurants, and find budget-friendly accommodations nearby.

sources.snippet: Home to one of Britain‚Äôs largest art collections, the Walker Art Gallery is a must-visit in Liverpool. The gallery features European art dating from the 14th century to the present, including work by Hockney, Rembrandt and Lowry. The gallery holds an extensive number of paintings, as well as sculptures and even fashion, making it a wonderful cultural hub.
sources.shortName: 25 Best Things to Do in Liverpool (England)

sources.snippet: Established in 1877, the Walker Art Gallery has housed some of Liverpool‚Äôs oldest and most impressive art collections. It has shown a range of collections, from painting and sculpture, to video art and photography.
sources.shortName: Places to see photography in Liverpool ‚Äì OEG

places.name: Walker Art Gallery

reviews.text: A fantastic art gallery packed with interesting and avant garde art. It can rival any London art gallery. It was not crowded even though we visited it during half term. There was a lute player in the Elizabethan art room, which made it very atmospheric, and the children loved it. Don't miss it!

I really enjoyed the gallery, it had an amazing mix of paintings in different styles, like Impressionism and Post-Impressionism. The variety is impressive, and the best part? It's free to visit! Definitely worth checking out.

As an art and architecture enthusiast, the Walker Art Gallery quickly became one of my favourite spots in Liverpool. From the moment you step inside, you're greeted with a sense of grandeur-elegant halls, beautifully lit galleries, and a layout that allows each piece to breathe while still flowing seamlessly between periods and styles.

The permanent collection is impressive, ranging from classical works to Victorian masterpieces and striking contemporary pieces. It's a joy to wander through the different rooms, each revealing new textures, colours, and stories. I always find myself lingering a little longer than expected, drawn in by both familiar favourites and hidden gems.

What I also truly appreciate are the occasional exhibitions. They bring a fresh energy to the space and offer new perspectives, often highlighting themes or artists that complement the main collection beautifully. These temporary displays feel thoughtfully curated and make each return visit feel like a new experience.

The building itself is just as inspiring as the art it holds-a stunning example of classical architecture that elevates the entire experience. Whether you're an art lover or simply curious, the Walker Art Gallery is a must-visit. It's a place where creativity, history, and beauty come together effortlessly.

places.address: William Brown St, Liverpool, L3 8EL, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: St George's Hall is a grand and iconic civic venue located in the heart of Liverpool. This neoclassical building houses a heritage center, an on-site cafe, and various event spaces. It stands as a testament to the city's wealth and civic aspirations in the 19th century. The hall hosts a range of events and concerts, with its highly decorated Great Hall being particularly noteworthy.

sources.snippet: St George‚Äôs Hall is an incredible Grade I listed Neoclassical landmark in the city and is a sight to see in the city. Head over to take in the scale of the building and for a few photos for your album. Inside you‚Äôll also find The History Whisperer, an interactive journey which tells the story of the history of the building and Homebaked and local cafe serving up the best homemade pies around!
sources.shortName: VisitLiverpool | Liverpool's Best Instagram Locations

sources.snippet: St George‚Äôs Hall is a magnificent Neoclassical building that dominates the heart of Liverpool‚Äôs city centre. This Grade I listed building is one of the finest examples of Neoclassical architecture in the UK, and is a popular spot for photography. The stunning interior includes a large hall, a small concert hall, and a beautiful entrance hall with a stunning chandelier.
sources.shortName: Top Liverpool Photo Spots: Scenic & Iconic Locations

sources.snippet: This historic town hall is considered to be one of the best examples in the entire world of neo-Grecian architecture. In essence, that means that it has a set of stunning columns flanking the exterior that will look fantastic in any photo. Whether you choose to shoot up close or from a distance, including the Hall in your photograph is a smart move.
sources.shortName: Spots you‚Äôll want to s

sources.snippet: Considered the centre of the city, St. George‚Äôs Hall sits opposite the Lime Street railway station. Designated as a Grade I listed building by English Heritage, the Hall houses a number of concert halls and law courts. Completed in 1854, it has notable Greek and Roman architectural features.
sources.shortName: 12 Amazing Places to Take Photographs in Liverpool

places.name: St George's Hall

reviews.text: St Georges Hall is one of the most magnificent buildings in Liverpool. As a modern city wedding photographer, it's always a pleasure to shoot in and around the hall. It makes such a beautiful backdrop for couple, bridal party, family & confetti photos. When it's raining, the covered area with the large pillars is a great place to take a couple for their photos too. It's also easy to walk round the corner to William Brown Street that has the trees lining the street, as well as other amazing sandstone buildings, such as Walker Art Gallery, County Sessions House and the Public Library.

Great candlelight moment with my wife ‚ù§Ô∏è.  different theme, just looking on a fever app and enjoying it.  Musicians are really friendly and bring beautiful entertainment between each music . Price is really cheap and a beautiful place .

Went to the Clink and Court Tour James our guide was very informative and kept the tour entertaining and interesting. After that part of the tour, John one of the volunteers  took over he was really nice and funny with lots of stories to tell. All in all very enjoyable.

places.address: St George's Pl, Liverpool, L1 1JJ, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: The Cavern Club is a historic venue located in Liverpool, known for its intimate atmosphere and 1960s memorabilia. It hosts live tribute acts day and night, making it a must-visit for music enthusiasts. Situated in the vibrant nightlife quarter of Victoria Street, it offers a unique experience with its brick vaulted cellars and lively entertainment.

sources.snippet: Sitting in a historic cellar, the Cavern Club has hosted dozens of live music every night, featuring popular artists such as the Beatles, who played here during their early careers. The insides might seem a little spooky but still aesthetically pleasing which would compel you to take out your cameras and start clicking. No wonder it is one of the best places for selfies in Liverpool.
sources.shortName: 20 Top Photography Spots In Liverpool: From Cafes To Museums

sources.snippet: It doesn‚Äôt get much better than the most famous club in the world as a backdrop for your group photo. The Cavern Club on Mathew Street welcomed The Beatles to their stage 292 times during their early days and has been a must visit spot ever since. Head down into the basement to enjoy the live music or stand beneath the sign for the ultimate selfie.
sources.shortName: VisitLiverpool | Liverpool's Best Instagram Locations

sources.snippet: The Cavern Club is infamous in the music scene as the home of The Beatles during their early years. The Cavern Club originally opened in 1957 as a jazz club and quickly became the hub of rock and roll during the 1960s. John Lennon, Paul McCartney and George Harrison each played here with other bands before forming The Beatles.
sources.shortName: 25 Best Things to Do in Liverpool (England)

places.name: The Cavern Club

reviews.text: Totally amazing, be careful on the steps going down. Live music every day, awesome memorabilia every where, some rare guitars, drums clothes. They do have a goods lift at the rear, need to ask at the entrance to use it, must be accompanied by a member of staff, someone with a disability scooter was in the club. Enjoy

Probably the most famous club in the world. Bands doing short sets then change to another band. Plenty of memorabilia to look at around the walls and obviously plenty of Beatles covers by all bands. Decent selection of drinks and plenty of staff serving. But, the bar is CASHLESS. Also, a very varied age range of clientele,  ranging from 20 to 70. Nice.

A must go place if you visit Liverpool. Fab experience and superb atmosphere. The pub is small and compact with low ceilings, but that's exactly what you look. Wide variety of drinks including alcohol free beer. Price is similar to other pubs, surprisingly reasonable. It got a souvenir shop as well selling techies, cups and other Cavern Club accessories. An awesome cultural experience and the best pub we ever visited.

places.address: 8, 10 Mathew St, Liverpool L2 6RE, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: Sefton Park Palm House is a stunning Victorian glasshouse located in Sefton Park, offering free admission to visitors every day. The Grade II* listed building features an elegant design that shines in the summer sun. Inside, the multi-million pound restored exotic palm house showcases vibrant vegetation in themed botanical displays, creating a tranquil escape from the city. The venue hosts various events throughout the year, including music and dance performances like the Free Sunday Concert.

sources.snippet: Sefton Park is one of the most beautiful city parks in the entire country, and there is plenty to stare in wonder at and get that perfect glare of the sun as you take a selfie on the field or find that reflection on the water of the boating lake. The Palm House is the perfect spot within the park, full of tropical plants at every corner you‚Äôll get lost in the heavenly scent and relaxing atmosphere.
sources.shortName: most-instagrammable-venues-and-locations-in-liverpool | featured

sources.snippet: A botanical HEAVEN, you‚Äôd be a fool to miss out on the chance to get this on your gram this summer. The perfect place to escape the hustle and bustle of the city centre, the Palm House is the jewel in the crown of Liverpool‚Äôs Sefton Park. Filled to the brim with tropical plants and hanging blossoms of every colour, this place is a feast for the eyes and your camera lense.
sources.shortName: No Filter Required - 15 Of Liverpool‚Äôs Most Instagrammable Spots

sources.snippet: The Palm House at Sefton Park is one place to visit to capture a shot like no other. From the ravishing tropical greenery cascaded around this striking glasshouse to the impressive hanging blossoms in every colour under the sun, this fairy tale haven will leave your camera roll beaming with beauty. READ MORE:LIVERPOOL‚ÄôS COCKTAIL BARS
sources.shortName: Instagrammable spots in Liverpool you need to check out

sources.snippet: If you are coming from London to Liverpool by car via the south entrance of the city, you will see a great piece of Victorian architecture in Sefton Park. It is a glass greenhouse, a beautiful Palm House, the botanical haven for tropical plants. Here, you can escape from the city's bustle.
sources.shortName: 12 Instagrammable places in Liverpool

places.name: Sefton Park Palm House

reviews.text: It's always a joy to shoot at Sefton Park Palm House - as a Liverpool wedding photographer it's one of my fave venues. A restored Victorian green house that's like an oasis in the city, full of tropical plants and history. I've shot winter, summer and autumnal weddings here - some of them were icy, some were rainy, some were sunny, but all of them were joyous and beautiful. The venue has a bar area, a relaxing seated area and a main hall for dining and dancing. It looks amazing when the sun streams in but also equally amazing when it's lit up at nighttime. The park around it offers some incredible backdrops for couple portraits, especially the mini forest of super tall evergreen trees, merely 2 minutes walk from the venue. Sunsets are always epic here, being able to see the sky turn pink from your dinner table is just gorgeous. As a supplier I've always been welcomed and fed well, which makes such a difference to my day. Can't wait to shoot there again!

We celebrated our wedding at the Palm House and we couldn't have picked a better venue. We'd visited multiple times before the big day but it was still completely magical to have our wedding there and feel the buzz of excitement from all of our guests seeing such a beautiful venue for the first time. We've had so many comments about how stunning the building was - we're glad it was a somewhat overcast day so it wasn't too hot inside! The team were also fantastic, from navigating complications over that weekend to being genuinely lovely people who were so excited for us, it really felt like the people were an important part of our day celebrating with us too. Thank you so much!

Fantastic to see this lovely historical old palm house restored and alive again. Compact in size, but amazing it's still here after it nearly was demolished because of years of neglect.
Tea room and ice-creams. Go visit, sit a while, and just enjoy!

places.address: Sefton Park, Liverpool, L17 1AP, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: St Luke‚Äôs Bombed Out Church, also known as St Luke's Church in Liverpool, is a historic landmark that was built in the early 19th century. The church, designed in Gothic style by John Foster Sr and John Foster Jr, served as both a place of worship and a concert hall. However, it suffered severe damage during the Liverpool Blitz of World War II, leaving it without a roof and with its stained glass shattered.

sources.snippet: The church with no roof, damaged in a bombing raid during the Second World War, St Luke‚Äôs Church (or the Bombed Out Church as it is affectionately known by locals) has been a place of great art and culture in recent times. It hosts weddings, farmers markets, art pieces, outdoor cinema nights and live music, and the interior, surrounding gardens and the steps of the Bombed Out Church make for some great photo ops.
sources.shortName: most-instagrammable-venues-and-locations-in-liverpool | featured

sources.snippet: The May Blitz of 1941 saw St Luke‚Äôs church forever changed when a bomb landed right on top of it‚Äôs roof. Over time, the city has lovingly restored it back to life and it now plays host to everything from weddings, complete with fun photo booths from Special Events Photo Booths to gigs, to farmers markets and cinema screenings. The church itself and the gardens around it are a total treat for the eye.
sources.shortName: No Filter Required - 15 Of Liverpool‚Äôs Most Instagrammable Spots

sources.snippet: St. Luke's Church was bombed out during WW II in the 1940s by Nazis like other cities from London to Liverpool and after that is called Bombed out Church. However, its remaining parts, gardens and cafes around the church and its revival gorgeousness with the roofless building still attract many visitors and make the site one of the great areas of Liverpool to take photos for your Instagram account.
sources.shortName: 12 Instagrammable places in Liverpool

sources.snippet: St Luke‚Äôs Church, or the Bombed Out Church as the locals call it, sits proudly at the top of Bold Street and is a great spot for a photograph, especially if you get to head inside. The Church is known as the Bombed Out Church due to the damage its roof took during‚Ä¶. But the walls now house a space used for everything from cinema nights to beer festivals, art commissions and gigs.
sources.shortName: VisitLiverpool | Liverpool's Best Instagram Locations

sources.snippet: St Luke‚Äôs church is stunning no matter what time of year or season and is of course known to us locals as the Bombed Out Church!. Whether snapping the church itself, or the gardens around it, this roofless building is chilling in the winter but also so stunningly eye-catching in the summer months.
sources.shortName: Instagrammable spots in Liverpool you need to check out

sources.snippet: Another spooky Liverpool photo spots includes the St Luke‚Äôs Bombed Out Church. As the name speaks for itself, the church is popular for its bombed-out state as a memorial to the martyrs of the Second World War. The bombed-out state makes it one of the fascinating Photography Spots In Liverpool.
sources.shortName: 20 Top Photography Spots In Liverpool: From Cafes To Museums

sources.snippet: Another stunning Instagrammable spot in Liverpool is St. Luke‚Äôs Church, or the Bombed Out Church, how it‚Äôs often referred to. St. Luke‚Äôs Church lost its roof during the WWII Blitz and wasn‚Äôt restored. Right now, it‚Äôs a wedding venue/cafe and a unique spot to visit in Liverpool.
sources.shortName: 10+ Amazing Instagrammable Places in Liverpool (+ their exact locations)

sources.snippet: Also known as St. Luke‚Äôs Church, the Bombed-Out Church lost its roof during the World War II blitz and has now been transformed into a wedding venue, caf√© and a great spot for pictures. The church is incredible to look around and is also filled with so much history.
sources.shortName: Top 7 Instagram Spots in Liverpool

sources.snippet: A modest Anglican parish church, originally built in 1832, St. Luke‚Äôs was a victim of the Liverpool Blitz in 1941 and now stands as a roofless shell, a monument to those who were lost during the war.
sources.shortName: 12 Amazing Places to Take Photographs in Liverpool

places.name: St Luke‚Äôs Bombed Out Church

reviews.text: Stunning with really friendly helpful staff, I was there when they had a fair with lots of stalls and it was such a nice atmosphere with bar and seating outside, there were great things on offer. The building and garden surrounding is just so beautiful with such interesting story. Worth keeping an eye out for events there!

We headed to St Luke's Bombed out Church - What a serene place. The building itself was beautiful, surrounded by wonderful trees + nature. The statue of the English Soldier + German Soldier - both with their own country uniforms BUT exactly the same face - should absolutely make you stop and think - we're not so very different from each other really are we?
These statues commemorating the shaking of hands - before their Christmas Day truce - engaging in a game of football - simply just young ordinary men before again the horrors of war continued.
The grounds are inviting, peaceful, serene with music playing and the opportunity to order food and drinks. A friendly place where people meet for lunch - take a break from sightseeing - just to BE. It's lovely and maybe we all feel that spirit of connection through ' The Handshake ' ENJOY

Unfortunately it appeared shut when we attended.

‚ÄãSt. Luke's Church, affectionately known as the "Bombed Out Church," is a powerful symbol of Liverpool's history and resilience. The church's foundation was laid in 1811, and it was consecrated in 1831. It was designed by John Foster Sr. and his son, John Foster Jr., in a refined Gothic Revival style.
‚ÄãThe church earned its nickname during the devastating Liverpool Blitz in May 1941. An incendiary bomb hit the church, causing a fire that gutted the building and destroyed the roof and interior, leaving only the exterior walls and tower intact. The tower clock stopped at 3:36 AM, a poignant reminder of the moment the bombing occurred.
‚ÄãInstead of being demolished, the shell of the church was preserved as a memorial to the civilian casualties of World War II. Since 2007, it has been managed as a community arts venue and a space for peace and reflection.

‚ÄãOpening Hours:
‚ÄãThe church is generally open from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. from April to September and 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. from October to March, though these times can vary based on weather and scheduled events. It's recommended to check their official website for the latest updates. The gardens surrounding the church are typically open daily from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m.

places.address: Leece St, Liverpool, L1 2TR, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: Situated on the iconic Albert Dock, The Beatles Story Museum is a must-see for enthusiasts of the legendary band. It offers an immersive experience into the lives and journey of The Beatles through a collection of memorabilia, interactive displays, and cutting-edge exhibits. Visitors can trace the band's humble beginnings in Liverpool to their rise to global stardom.

sources.snippet: For music fans, a visit to Liverpool isn‚Äôt complete without experiencing The Beatles Story. This exhibition is dedicated to telling the history and influence of the international phenomenon, The Beatles. The exhibition features a range of artefacts from the Beatles and their career, including John Lennon‚Äôs round glasses, George Harrison‚Äôs first guitar, rare photographs and other memorabilia.
sources.shortName: 25 Best Things to Do in Liverpool (England)

sources.snippet: Delve into an interactive exhibit that takes you on a journey through the life of the Beatles and how they started their journey from scratch and became the legend of the music industry. The museum contains replicas of the locations where the bands played which obviously includes the Cavern Club and the Abbey Road. You will receive an audio set with headsets to enhance your experience.
sources.shortName: 20 Top Photography Spots In Liverpool: From Cafes To Museums

places.name: The Beatles Story Museum, Liverpool

reviews.text:
This was one of my favorite stops in Liverpool! The museum was done very well with memorabilia documenting the bands rise to fame. There were a lot of built displays such as the yellow submarine, the magical mystery bus, and clubs like the Cavern. Each exhibit has a number to correspond with the audio guided tour. Headphones and a handset are provided with the cost of entry. You don't need to worry about your phone losing battery or signal to hear all of the facts along the way.
Signed memorabilia and Beatles merchandise is displayed throughout the museum. Original song lyrics written by the band and producers. Sgt Pepper and A Hard Days Night outfits are on display. Cartoon cells from The Yellow Submarine.
The audio guide was informative but a bit long winded at times. There is obviously Beatles music playing throughout the different exhibits to correspond with the display.
Each member of the band has a specific section dedicated to their lives. There are actual instruments played by the Beatles and items they have owned.
At the end, there is a recreation of John Lennon and Yoko Ono's white room. A pair of Lennon's round framed eyeglasses sit atop a pedestal in the middle. Many of his sketches are hung on the walls. Great gift shop at the end. They have a small cafe with ready made items. The area is full of many other things to do so pay for parking and explore. Lots of restaurants, a shopping mall, and multiple activities (carousel, light show, etc).
We went on a Friday afternoon. Museum was relatively quiet. No wait to enter.

The Beatles Story Museum was different than I  anticipated, but highly enjoyable!  We were greeted by kind and welcoming staff at the door and purchased tickets when we arrived.  The ticket includes the audio guide, which isn't just an enhancement, but a really essential part of the visit.  The audio guide tells the story of the Beatles as you move from room to room.  So it's a combination of recreations and memorabilia, organized in a way to walk you through their story.  I found it interesting and insightful.  We were there just over an hour, though your visit could be longer if you listened to every bonus video and feature on the audio guide.  Self-guided tour ends with a cafe and then a huge gift shop.  So glad we did this when visiting Liverpool.  It was different than anticipated, but in a good way!

Tucked into the iconic Albert Dock, The Beatles Story Museum is nothing short of a pilgrimage site for music lovers, dreamers, and die-hard Beatles fans. From the moment you step through its doors, you're whisked away on a nostalgic journey through the life, music, and legacy of the Fab Four.

The experience is masterfully immersive. Each exhibit feels like stepping into a time capsule-recreations of The Cavern Club, Abbey Road Studios, and even the psychedelic brilliance of Sgt. Pepper-era magic are all brought to life with authentic detail. The audio guide, narrated by those close to the band, adds depth and emotion, weaving personal anecdotes with historical insight.

It's more than a museum-it's a heartbeat of 60s culture, vibrating with Lennon's wit, McCartney's melodies, Harrison's soul, and Starr's rhythm. Rare memorabilia, original instruments, and poignant interviews paint a vivid portrait of four lads from Liverpool who changed the world.

The gift shop is a treasure trove for collectors, and the caf√© offers the perfect spot to reflect while ‚ÄúLet It Be‚Äù plays softly in the background.

Whether you're a lifelong fan or a curious newcomer, The Beatles Story is a must-visit. It's heartfelt, informative, and genuinely magical-a love letter to the band that made the world sing!

places.address: Britannia Vaults, Royal Albert Dock, Liverpool L3 4AD, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: Crosby Beach, located just half an hour north of central Liverpool, offers a captivating experience for visitors. The beach is adorned with a striking installation called Another Place by renowned sculptor Antony Gormley, featuring 100 life-size figures spread across two miles of the coastline. These iron casts of the artist's body create a mesmerizing sight against the backdrop of the sea and sky, constantly changing with the tides and weather.

sources.snippet: A post shared by BakerBoots1980 (@bakerboots1980) on Sep 9, 2018 at 4:15am PDT. Crosby Beach is the permanent home of Anthony Gormley‚Äôs wonderful ‚ÄúAnother Place‚Äù modern sculpture. Consisting of 100 cast iron figures facing towards the sea, there are so many different options for great photos here.

sources.snippet: If you want to get out of the hustle and bustle of the city you have Crosby Beach less than half an hour away. You can take a stroll along from the marina to the beach, cuddle in the sand dunes or pose with the famous Iron Men. If it‚Äôs a nice day I might even let you treat me to an ice-cream!

places.generalDescription: Tate Liverpool is a renowned art museum housed in converted dock buildings, showcasing both temporary and permanent contemporary international art exhibitions. Situated in the heart of Liverpool, it offers a diverse collection spanning centuries and various styles. Visitors can admire works by iconic artists such as Rembrandt, van Gogh, and Picasso alongside contemporary pieces.

sources.snippet: Liverpool is famous for its art collections and Tate Liverpool is one of its most well-known galleries. Tate Liverpool features work from the Tate Collection which showcases British art from the 16th century to the present. Tate Liverpool specialises in contemporary and modern art.

I didn't notice the ‚Äúclosed‚Äù notice on Google, so I couldn't find the entrance and ended up wandering around for 30 minutes. Make sure to check the reopening schedule before you visit!

The creative area for kids is good. It is a good option for keeping kids involved in activities.
Art section is good.
Two galleries to see. Nice and polite staff.

places.generalDescription: The Bluecoat is a historic creative center located in a Queen Anne-style building in Liverpool. It is housed in the city's oldest building, dating back to the early 18th century and boasting UNESCO world heritage and Grade-listed status. The gallery has a rich history, having hosted the first Post Impressionist exhibition in 1911 with works by renowned artists like Picasso, Cezanne, Van Gogh, Matisse, and Gauguin.

sources.snippet: The Bluecoat is an aesthetic art centre in a Queen Anne-style building, that features some top-notch exhibitions and theatrical events. Besides the entertainment, the Bluecoat is an absolute beauty with its stunning architecture, making it among the popular Photo spots in Liverpool. Location: 8 School Ln, Liverpool, L1 3BX.

Only one downside as we were loading on the Sunday, with full permission from The Bluecoat, 5 of us received parking tickets within a 6 minute window, even though our boots were open and hazard lights on!!! So much for supporting local small businesses!
My new favourite cafe and gardens. Food was so good and well priced.
A lovely oasis in the heart of the city centre. Beautiful building with a large,  peaceful, courtyard garden. Interesting exhibits and a nice cafe.

places.generalDescription: Liverpool Metropolitan Cathedral is a circular Roman Catholic place of worship featuring contemporary art. It was built in the 1960s after previous attempts to construct a cathedral fell through. The stunning modern gothic revival architecture makes it a must-see attraction in Liverpool, especially for those interested in religious and historical landmarks. The cathedral's unique design and artistic elements make it an essential stop for visitors looking to experience the local culture and architectural heritage of the city.

sources.snippet: Looking for Photography Spots In Liverpool that will make your Instagram followers lose their minds?. Since you have scrolled down so far, we are guessing, you really need some cool pictures to give your Instagram feed up a notch, with some of the best Instagrammable Places in Liverpool. If that is the case, then head straight to the Liverpool Metropolitan Cathedral, which is the largest in the United Kingdom and the fifth largest in Europe, making it one of the top Photo Shoot Locations in Liverpool.
sources.shortName: 20 Top Photography Spots In Liverpool: From Cafes To Museums

sources.snippet: Liverpool is home to several photogenic cathedrals, but the Metropolitan Cathedral is probably one of the most unusual buildings in the whole of the UK. Reminiscent of an alien ship landed in the middle of a city, the inside is also verging on the surreal. Whether you photograph the exterior or interior you‚Äôre bound to get something to add to your portfolio.
sources.shortName: Spots you‚Äôll want to s

sources.snippet: The Liverpool Metropolitan Cathedral is the city‚Äôs second cathedral, having been built in 1967. This cathedral is nicknamed the ‚ÄúCatholic Cathedral‚Äù to distinguish it from the Anglican Liverpool Cathedral. The cathedral is the largest Catholic cathedral in Britain and serves the vast Catholic community in Liverpool.
sources.shortName: 25 Best Things to Do in Liverpool (England)

places.name: Liverpool Metropolitan Cathedral

reviews.text:
The Liverpool Metropolitan Cathedral is a dazzling icon of modern architecture-affectionately nicknamed ‚ÄúPaddy's Wigwam,‚Äù but don't let the nickname fool you. This place is absolutely stunning.

With its circular design and towering crown-like spire, the cathedral stands boldly against the city skyline, a symbol of innovation and inclusivity. Step inside, and you're immediately wrapped in a kaleidoscope of colour and light. The stained-glass lantern ceiling is the star of the show-casting rich blues, reds, and golds that shift as the sun moves, bathing the interior in an ever-changing glow. It's both peaceful and electric.

The design encourages reflection without formality. There's space to wander, space to breathe, and space to be still. It's modern, yet deeply spiritual-minimalist, yet full of feeling.

Outside, the open plaza is a social, sunlit space that invites visitors to sit, snap photos, or simply soak in the view of this architectural gem. It's a perfect spot to pause and admire how seamlessly the cathedral blends bold design with a strong sense of purpose.

Whether you're into architecture, art, or serenity with a splash of colour-this cathedral will leave a lasting impression.

One negative, would be that we were not allowed to bring our small dog inside, even though it said on the website you could!!

SIMPLY WOW - I'm not a person on religion but this Cathedral was something else. It's grandeur, its presence truly invites you in just to look. A warm welcome to look around given to ALL - free if charge - ( you can make a donation if you choose to).
It's ASTOUNDING - the architecture, the lighting, the colours, the statues - ACTUALLY EVERYTHING.
Take time to look at each alcove dedicated to different things - THEN step back far enough away to take in also the opening above it - which seems to give completion! When I noticed that myself it was quite beautiful.
The 14 stages of Christ ( I think they are called) some a little 'gruesome' (for me) but absolutely spectacular art.
The organ pipes ( ask how many - wow) then see if you can spot where the organ is!!
This circular building is profoundly beautiful and for those who follow this faith - I just can't imagine how it must make you feel.
The crypts - another incredible space and well worth the ¬£5 charge to visit.
There IS a sense of peace, of quiet within oneself - surrounded by all of this colour, shade, light and utter brilliance. Don't miss this from your visit. Don't be put off by a faith aspect - this incredible building and the people servicing it invite EVERYONE.

Remarkable cathedral completed in the 1960s, still in regular use and one of Liverpool's most recognisable landmarks.
The cathedral site was previously occupied by a workhouse, and the building seen today was the fourth design for a Catholic cathedral in Liverpool, the previous three having been abandoned due to cost and other constraints.
The cathedral occupies a commanding position within the city. Walking up the steps to the entrance, visitors can fully appreciate its presence. Inside, several separate chapels surround a large central space. The simple design and modern stained glass are very different to the gothic cathedrals of the past.
The cathedral is free to visit (donations welcomed) though a charge applies to see the Lutyens Crypt. It's a little bit of a walk from the city centre, but worth the effort to see such an unusual building. It's simplicity compared to ornately detailed gothic cathedrals of the past means it doesn't take long to fully explore.

places.address: Cathedral House, Mount Pleasant, Liverpool L3 5TQ, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: Junkyard Golf Club in Liverpool is not your average crazy golf venue. It features 9-hole courses filled with colorful and quirky elements like scrap yard slides, wrecked car parts, circus freaks, and jungle bathtubs. The venue also offers Instagrammable cocktails and a vibrant atmosphere that's perfect for a fun night out with friends or a unique date idea. Whether you're a first-time player or a seasoned pro, Junkyard Golf Club promises an entertaining experience for all.

sources.snippet: @sams_adventures_x ‚Äì Junk Yard Golf, home to crazy courses, weird cocktails and all things junk!. So much more than your average crazy golf venue, with pimped out scrapyard cars, Neon signs and Instagrammable cocktails, the new Liverpool venue is a selfie taking hotspot!. What‚Äôs your ‚Äòtop tip‚Äô for capturing the perfect insta-worthy pic?

sources.snippet: Every hole is a selfie opportunity, with nine holes across 3 crazy courses. Each course has its own unique theme, think UV garage, scrapyard slides, circus freaks and jungle bathtubs. Base guests are lucky enough to receive 20% off Sunday ‚Äì Thursday.

places.name: Junkyard Golf Club | Crazy Golf Liverpool

reviews.text: We LOVED this place! Nico and Cam made our night so much fun, it wouldn't have been the same without their excellent service. The courses are so cool (we loved the slide), the drinks are absolute works of art and tasted incredible. Wish we could have stayed longer :)

Fast, friendly service from the team at Junkyard Golf! We'd originally went to Roxy Lanes to play a game of bowling, but at ¬£10 per person, per game and with 3 of us looking to play, ¬£30 felt like a rip off, so we ended up in Junkyard instead, and such a treat it ended up being!

The staff are incredibly friendly and accommodating. We paid ¬£9.50 for 9 holes on the "Gary" Course. There was an option to pay ¬£12.50 for unlimited games, however we only had time for 1 game as we were heading to the airport straight after but that felt like a really great price, expecially because the course we did was so much fun! Challenging enough but enjoyable.

There were 2 groups ahead of us, and we got chatting with the ones directly ahead and the group behind, which made the whole experience really friendly. People asked us to take photos and in turn, offered to take photos of us all too.

I try to get to Liverpool once a year, and I'm so glad we tried Junkyard today, I'd definitely go back again next time I'm there!

We had a great time here. Not expensive, we had a couple of games each and were in there for over an hour. Been a few times now and will go again when we're in Liverpool.

The staff were great - very friendly and helpful, especially Ella who made a real effort, very much appreciated üëç

The equipment and facilities were in great condition and it was a really fun couple of games.

We didn't eat or drink there this time but have before and would again.

Overall, would recommend üòä

places.generalDescription: "For All Liverpool's Liver Birds (Wings) by Paul Curtis" is a must-see mural in Liverpool's Baltic Triangle on Jamaica Street. This iconic street art allows visitors to pose as the city's famous Liver Birds, creating memorable photo opportunities. Street art plays a significant role in expressing freedom, ideas, and emotions while adding character to urban landscapes. In addition to this mural, Liverpool boasts numerous other captivating street art pieces that contribute to the city's vibrant cultural scene.

sources.snippet: We have all seen the trend of taking pictures by standing in front of wings on the walls. If you are someone who fancies such things, there are a few Photo spots in Liverpool that give you exactly what you are looking for. You could head to Jamaica Street to witness this masterpiece of art, that allows tourists to become the Liver Birds and take some amazing pictures.

reviews.text: Great place to get a photo for your social media, the Paul Curtis artwork is known across Liverpool and the surrounding areas, he deserves a lot of credit. It's a good spot for anyone visiting too!

Jamaica Street in Liverpool's Baltic Triangle is a visual feast and a must-see for anyone into street art, culture, or just looking for a killer Instagram backdrop. The entire street is a constantly evolving canvas bursting with color, creativity, and attitude. One of the absolute highlights is the stunning pair of angel wings painted against a dark wall ‚Äì perfectly placed for that classic ‚ÄúI've ascended‚Äù photo op. It's almost a rite of passage to snap a pic there.

Further along the street, you'll find a powerful tribute to Jurgen Klopp, Liverpool's football messiah. It's more than just a mural ‚Äì it's a love letter from the city to the man who brought them glory. But the art doesn't stop there. From psychedelic portraits to politically charged pieces, Jamaica Street delivers a mix of humor, rebellion, and raw talent.

The beauty is in the variety ‚Äì no two visits are the same, as artists keep adding new layers to the urban story. Whether you're a tourist, a local, or a photographer on the hunt for inspiration, Jamaica Street is a bold, brilliant expression of Liverpool's creative soul. Get your camera ready ‚Äì this is art you don't just look at, you experience.

Awesome street art that caught me by surprise upon walking alongside it all.

Then it dawned on me...

Those wings are on almost every single scouse woman's dating photos and they seemed less impressive then. Everything else is great! Awesome place for taking pictures.

places.address: 43 Jamaica St, Liverpool, L1 0AH, United Kingdom

places.generalDescription: Central Library, the city's largest library, underwent a major renovation in 2013 and is a must-visit attraction. The library features a rooftop terrace and an impressive atrium staircase. As you approach the building, you'll encounter the Literary Pavement celebrating the city's literary contributions. Inside, you'll find a stunning atrium with an elliptical glass dome and the beautiful circular Picton Reading Room with rich wood shelving filled with books.

sources.snippet: If yes you are going to love this place, but if not, you are going to love it even more because of the architecture, atrium staircases, and rooftop terraces, making it among the best Photography Spots In Liverpool. The Central Library features a kids and children‚Äôs section, a coffee shop, and a multimedia zone, making it nothing less than a dream for photographers as well as book lovers, making it one of the best places to visit in Liverpool. Location: William Brown St, Liverpool, L3 8EW.
sources.shortName: 20 Top Photography Spots In Liverpool: From Cafes To Museums

sources.snippet: Located on the city‚Äôs historic William Brown Street, the library was originally constructed in 1860 with the additions of the Picton Reading Room in 1879 and the Hornby Library in 1906. The building recently went under a huge period of redevelopment that took 5 years, designed to bring the old buildings up to date with modern technological resources for the public.
sources.shortName: 12 Amazing Places to Take Photographs in Liverpool

sources.snippet: Stop off at Liverpool Central Library in St. Georges Quarter to explore one of the coolest libraries in the country. The Picton Reading room is like something off the set of Harry Potter, the roof terrace will give you stunning views over Liverpool and the Discovery Area will give the kids the chance to explore the world of literature.
sources.shortName: VisitLiverpool | Liverpool's Best Instagram Locations

sources.snippet: Historians say that before this library, the reader went from Liverpool to London to find books. Then Liverpool Central Library was built to prevent this difficulty. Picton Reading Room of the Library is the best spot, particularly if you are a reader of Harry Potter books because there are many books and pictures of him.
sources.shortName: 12 Instagrammable places in Liverpool

places.name: Central Library

reviews.text: Amazing architecture, plenty of books, multiple PC seats, and even a panoramic view at the top. Free entry. Can't ask for more. Would definitely spend time here if you've checked out everything else on your list.

A must go in Liverpool! Absolutely my favorite place in the city. Impeccable!

Plenty of books for all preferences, comfortable reading areas, PC seats available, kids area and all very calm, clean, organized. Discovered a lot of cool titles and had the best fun!

Free entry, pretty souvenirs and warm welcome from the staff. Great view on the terrace! Literally I could stay at this place for hours and hours - what a blast!

My personal bonus: Cool selection of architecture books and a mesmerizing architecture in itself.

Liverpool Central Library is a beautiful blend of heritage and modern design-an inspiring space that invites you to slow down, explore, and reflect. As someone who appreciates architectural details, I was immediately struck by the building's thoughtful layout and elegant features. The glass dome in particular is stunning-it floods the space with natural light, creating a calm and uplifting atmosphere that's perfect for reading or simply taking in your surroundings.

From the upper floors, the view over the city is a quiet surprise. It adds a wonderful sense of openness, connecting the library to the world beyond its walls while still feeling like a peaceful retreat. Whether you're browsing books, studying, or just passing through, there's a sense of calm and quiet beauty throughout the building.

What I also loved was the subtle use of colour-pops of warmth and brightness that soften the modern lines and give the space a welcoming, almost playful character. It's not just a place for books; it's a space that feels alive and well-loved.

Liverpool Central Library is more than just a library-it's an architectural and cultural landmark that encourages curiosity and creativity at every turn.

places.address: William Brown St, Liverpool, L3 8EW, United Kingdom

The venue is adorned with beautiful floral decorations throughout, creating a picturesque setting for visitors. Located in the Georgian Quarter on Hardman St, it's easily accessible from various accommodations in Liverpool.

places.name: The Florist Bar & Restaurant Liverpool

reviews.text:
I visited on Friday night with my mum. We sat at a lovely table with a nice view of outside and most of the restaurant. It was a lovely atmosphere - not very busy but a good few tables to create a fun vibe. The decor is STUNNING. Never seen a restaurant like it.

Mum ordered the salmon kebab and I had vegan lamb kofta. We also shared a cauliflower starter. The portion sizes were perfect - not too big but just enough. We also shared 2 bottles of wine.
The bill was reasonable - decent for what we had and the wine costing the most, but hey, it's a treat. Our waiter was charming, as were the rest of the staff.
All in all we both had a lovely evening and will be returning.

This is the epitome of instagram vs. reality. Sure, it's pretty, and there were loads of people taking photos of the decor. In reality, I found it quite grubby, with dirty stairs, that looked like someone had swept the dirt into the corners. The toilets were grim and out of paper, and the taps felt like they needed a drop of WD40. The staff seemed busy and stressed, which was reflected in the poor service. You had to scan a QR code for a gluten-free 5, which is fine, but the starters weren't on, and it took two staff to finally bring out a cardboard menu. It took forever for the starters to arrive, I had the Korean fried chicken. This was lukewarm and tasteless. Whilst we were waiting forever for the mains, we ordered another bottle of wine that was dumped on the table by a staff member who walked off without opening it. Thankfully, another one noticed and went to get a corkscrew. Eventually, the mains arrived, I had a Thai Prawn hanging kebab. It was bland, and the prawns were barely warm with rice that was hot in some places and cold in others. I left most of it, though it did look nice.
Overall, if you don't care about food and service and want to take some nice photos, this is the place. If you want decent food, go anywhere else.
Beautiful interior in a lovely building.  Very Instagramable.  Staff were lovely as we're the cocktails.  Food was good but nothing special.  I would have expected a little more ooh with the food.

places.address: 24 Hardman St, Liverpool, L1 9AX, United Kingdom
